subject: RE: [junit] Ant integration (was execution log file)
msgSnippet: Thanks Stefan, you have reassured me that I m taking the right approach. I traced my problem back to having an old version of optional.jar on my class path.
messageBody:
Thanks Stefan, you have reassured me that I'm taking the right approach.

I traced my problem back to having an old version of optional.jar on my
class path.

-----Original Message-----
From: Stefan Bodewig [mailto:bodewig@...]
Sent: 05 July 2001 09:34
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Ant integration (was execution log file)


On Wed, 4 Jul 2001, David Roussel <dir@...> wrote:

> I had look back though the archives and I found some junit/ant posts
> to/from Yishay, but I didn't find any special steps that need to be
> taken. I've got my class path set with all the junit and ant jars
> but it don't work out of the box.

Actually, in the simplest possible setup, you put junit.jar into your
CLASSPATH, install Ant 1.3 (1.2 should work as well) and place the
corresponding optional jar file in ANT_HOME/lib. This should work out
of the box.

Reasons why the integration doesn't work as expected for some people
are:

(1) They don't want junit.jar in the CLASSPATH - if you do so, you
must use <taskdef> to define the task with a custom classpath *and*
the task definition itself (from optional.jar) must not live in
ANT_HOME/lib (specify it explicitly in the taskdef as well).

(2) They don't run the version of Ant they want to run. Some tools
ship with an old version of Ant that somehow gets into their
CLASSPATH.

Stefan
